section.title: Basic operations
section.para: We now introduce the most basic operations you can perform in JSONiq.

section.title: Comma operator
section.para: Use a comma to concatenate two sequences, or even single items. This operator has the lowest precedence of all.
Sequences do not nest. You need to use arrays in order to nest.

section.title: Range operator
section.para: With the binary operator "to", you can generate larger sequences with just two integer operands.
If one operand evaluates to the empty sequence, then the range operator returns the empty sequence.

example.title: Range operator with the empty sequence

section.para: Otherwise, if an operand evaluates to something else than a single integer or an empty sequence, an error is raised.

example.title: Range operator with a type inconsistency

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: sequence of more than one item can not be promoted to parameter type xs:integer? of function to()

section.title: Parenthesized expression
section.para: Use parentheses to override the precedence of expressions.
If the parentheses are empty, the empty sequence is produced.

section.title: Arithmetics
section.para: JSONiq supports the basic four operations, integer division and modulo.
Multiplicative operations have precedence over additive operations. Parentheses can override it.

example.title: Basic arithmetic operations with precedence override

section.para: Dates, times and durations are also supported in a natural way.
If any of the operands is a sequence of more than one item, an error is raised.

example.title: Sequence of more than one number in an addition

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: sequence of more than one item can not be promoted to parameter type xs:anyAtomicType? of function add()

section.para: If any of the operands is not a number, a date, a time or a duration, an error is raised.

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: arithmetic operation not defined between types "xs:integer" and "js:null"

section.para: If one of the operands evaluates to the empty sequence, then the operation results in the empty sequence.
Do not worry if the two operands do not have the same number type, JSONiq will do the adequate conversions.

example.title: Basic arithmetic operations with an empty sequence

section.title: String concatenation
section.para: Two strings or more can be concatenated using the concatenation operator.
An empty sequence is treated like an empty string.

example.title: String concatenation with the empty sequence

section.title: Comparison
section.para: Atomics can be compared with the usual six comparison operators (equality, non-equality, lower-than, greater-than, lower-or-equal, greater-or-equal), and with the same two-letter symbols as in MongoDB.
Comparison is only possible between two compatible types, otherwise, an error is raised.

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: "xs:string": invalid type: can not compare for equality to type "xs:integer"

section.para: null can be compared for equality or inequality to anything - it is only equal to itself so that false is returned when comparing if for equality with any non-null atomic. True is returned when comparing it with non-equality with any non-null atomic.

example.title: Equality and non-equality comparison with null
example.programlisting: 1 eq null, "foo" ne null, null eq null

section.para: For ordering operators (lt, le, gt, ge), null is considered the smallest possible value (like in JavaScript).
Like for arithmetic operations, if an operand is the empty sequence, the empty sequence is returned as well.

Comparisons and logic operators are fundamental for a query language and for the implementation of a query processor as they impact query optimization greatly. The current comparison semantics for them is carefully chosen to have the right characteristics as to enable optimization.

section.title: Logics
section.para: JSONiq logics support is based on two-valued logics: just true and false.
Non-boolean operands get automatically converted to either true or false, or an error is raised. The boolean() function performs a manual conversion.

listitem.para: An empty sequence is converted to false.
A singleton sequence of one null is converted to false.
A singleton sequence of one string is converted to true except the empty string which is converted to false.
A singleton sequence of one number is converted to true except zero or NaN which are converted to false.
An operand singleton sequence whose first item is an object or array is converted to true.
Other operand sequences cannot be converted and an error is raised.

section.para: JSONiq supports the most famous three boolean operations: conjunction, disjunction and negation. Negation has the highest precedence, then conjunction, then disjunction. Parentheses can override.

example.title: Logics with booleans
example.programlisting: true and ( true or not true )

example.title: Conversion of the empty sequence to false
Conversion of a string to true
Conversion of a number to false
Conversion of an object to a boolean (not implemented in Zorba at this point)

section.para: If the input sequence has more than one item, and the first item is not an object or array, an error is raised.

example.title: Error upon conversion of a sequence of more than one item, not beginning with a JSON item, to a boolean

formalpara.title: Result (run with Zorba):
formalpara.para: An error was raised: invalid argument type for function fn:boolean(): effective boolean value not defined for sequence of more than one item that starts with "xs:integer"

section.para: Unlike in C++ or Java, you cannot rely on the order of evaluation of the operands of a boolean operation. The following query may return true or may return an error.
It is possible to perform a conjunction or a disjunction on a predicate for each item in a sequence.

example.title: Existential quantifier on several variables
example.programlisting: some $i in -5 to 5, $j in 1 to 10 satisfies $i eq $j

section.para: Variables can be annotated with a type. If no type is specified, item* is assumed. If the type does not match, an error is raised.

example.title: Existential quantifier with type checking
example.programlisting: some $i as integer in -5 to 5, $j as integer in 1 to 10 satisfies $i eq $j
